Award.AwardTitle: In Situ Neutron Diffraction and Fluid Dynamics Modeling of Dynamic Recrystallization in Mg Alloys
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The objective of this project is to investigate the underlying physics of dynamic recrystallization in magnesium alloys during severe plastic deformation at elevated temperatures. Dynamic recrystallization involves the creation of new grains with low dislocation densities in a deformed microstructure during deformation. Dynamic recrystallization can strongly influence the mechanical properties in the variety of wrought metals and alloys used for structural applications. Friction-stir processing will be used to produce large plastic strains in specimens of commercial magnesium alloy AZ31. The transient nature of dynamic recrystallization and the critical role that twinning plays on grain refinement and crystallographic texture development in this magnesium alloy will be studied using in-situ, real-time neutron and synchrotron X-ray diffraction measurements and computational fluid dynamics (CFD) modeling. The research consists of three primary tasks: (1) develop a portable friction-stir-processing machine for use in in-situ diffraction studies; (2) in-situ, real-time diffraction measurements during plastic deformation to study the transient evolution of microstructure, namely texture, internal strain, dislocation density, subgrain size and twin density; and (3) computational fluid dynamics simulation of plastic deformation to study material flow rate and flow patterns in reference to temperature distribution and evolution. Simulation predictions will be correlated to microstructure evolution data to identify the dynamic recrystallization mechanisms responsible for microstructure development. Education, training and outreach activities will include high-school, undergraduate and graduate students. A new course on neutron diffraction will be developed.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
Dynamic recrystallization is a complex phenomenon that occurs in metals and alloys while they are deformed, usually at elevated temperatures. It can significantly change the microstructure and properties of a material, either detrimentally or advantageously. The objective of this project is to investigate the mechanisms by which dynamic recrystallization occurs. This research will incorporate a magnesium alloy, AZ31, of interest for light-weighting vehicles. It will also use friction stir processing, which is of interest for advanced manufacturing. These will be combined with advanced diffraction experiments to study the underlying mechanisms of dynamic recrystallization. Education, training and outreach activities will include high-school, undergraduate and graduate students. A new course on neutron diffraction will be developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The orientation of crystals (so called crystallographic texture) in structural metallic alloys is one of the most significant factors governing the formability during manufacturing processes. In particular, the crystallographic texture of magnesium (Mg) alloys is well known to influence on how well this material can be deformed during forming processes. Recently developed friction stir processing (FSP) technique demonstrated that it can be used to manipulate the microstructure and texture of Mg alloys. In order to control the texture of friction stir processed Mg alloy, it is necessary to understand the fundamentals of microstructure development involving dynamic recrystallization (DRX) and texture development during the FSP.

In this study, a comprehensive in-situ and ex-situ diffraction study was carried out to investigate the basic mechanisms of the DRX process using both x-rays and neutrons as major probing tools. First, in order to understand the effect of temperature, strain rate, and resulting Zener-Hollomon parameter (Z) on the grain size refinement and texture development, a constitutive study was carried out by conducting a series of hot compression tests using a Gleeble system. The changes in dominant deformation mechanisms (from dislocation slip to twinning) yielded significant changes in texture and dynamic recrystallization behavior. The combined effects of texture and grain size refinement on mechanical properties were also examined by conducting tensile mechanical tests on the DRXed samples. And, then to further unravel the texture evolutions during FSP, we measured the texture development in a Mg alloy plate during the FSP at two different thermo-mechanical input conditions, namely, low Z (LZ) and high Z (HZ) conditions using in situ neutron diffraction with a portable FSP machine. The in-situ neutron diffraction results provided a unique insights to a transient texture development during the FSP otherwise difficult to probe.

The current research contributes to: (1) the advances in the fundamental understanding of the physics of dynamic recrystallization mechanisms and microstructure development in Mg alloys during FSP, (2) development of characterization methodology of advanced diffraction techniques that can be applied to FSP and other thermo-mechanical processing and manufacturing techniques, and (3) facilitation of transformational advances in the FSP technology and potential new industrial applications.

Moreover, the successful development of ultrafine-grained Mg alloys with optimum texture component will allow superplastic forming of Mg alloys at lower temperature and higher strain rates. It will result in a significant improvement in the formability of Mg alloys and open new doors for many meaningful commercial applications, e.g., in the area of transportation industry. For example, significant improvements in the formability of Mg alloys could transform the automotive industry in that the current steel and/or aluminum alloy components can be replace by much lighter Mg alloys for markedly improved fuel efficiency.

Dr. Yuan Li, a former PhD student who worked on this project, graduated from the University of Tennessee in December 2019. He is now working at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory as a postdoctoral research associate.
